Title: Where to Watch & Read Requiem of the Rose King
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Requiem of the Rose King: How to Get Started With the Anime & Manga    Requiem of the Rose King: How to Get Started With the Anime & Manga  By Timothy Donohoo Published 9 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Requiem of the Rose King reimagines Shakespeare in a strangely beautiful way, and the anime has only now started as the manga has ended.                 Many works throughout the decades have adapted and re-imagined the writings of William Shakespeare, but perhaps none more so than Requiem of the Rose King. Combining two Shakespeare plays into one, the result is an entirely different story altogether. The original manga recently came to an end just as the anime began, with two versions of the very altered history now available.  History and literature buffs who think they know the story already are in for several surprises, while those who don't even like Shakespeare are sure to find something that they enjoy in the franchise. Here's more on what Requiem of the Rose King is about, as well as how to read and watch the different versions of it. RELATED: How to Get Started With K-On!          The Plot of Requiem of the Rose King                 Requiem of the Rose King loosely combines elements of William Shakespeare's Henry VI, Part 3 and Richard III, turning the War of the Roses completely on its head. In the story, the Houses of York and Lancaster battle over England, with the House of York losing its leader to a deadly enemy attack. Left in the wake of this loss is Richard III, the king's intersex son who identifies as male. Richard is hated and feared by many around him, including his own mother, all while spirits torture and subjugate him. Forced into an unlikely situation, Richard prepares to defend his house while dealing with external and internal threats.  RELATED: How to Get Started With Ouran High School Host Club          Where to Read the Requiem of the Rose King Manga                 Requiem of the Rose King began as a manga from Aya Kanno in October 2013, being published in the magazine Monthly Princess. The series ran for almost nine years, ending in early 2022. In the West, the series has been localized by Viz Media, with 14 of the 17 volumes having been released in English-speaking territories. The series has two spin-offs: King of Idol: Bara-Ō no Gakuen and Bara-Ō no Sōretsu: Gaiden. The former is a more humorous spin-off where the characters are in high school studying to become entertainers, while the latter focuses on events not shown in the main series. Since both of them only began in the last year, neither has yet been localized. The main series' manga can be purchased physically wherever manga is sold, including Walmart, Books-a-Million, Barnes & Noble and Amazon, while Kindle and Comixology carry the digital version.  RELATED: How to Get Started With Bakuman          Where to Watch the Requiem of the Rose King Anime                The anime adaptation of the series began airing in January 2022, just as the manga ended, although it was originally intended to come out in late 2021. Requiem of the Rose King was animated by J.C. Staff, a well-known studio whose recent works include the anime for How a Realist Hero Rebuilt the Kingdom as well as Is It Wrong to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon?. The result is a series with beautiful, breathtaking art, befitting the nature of the characters. So far, 13 episodes have aired in Japan, with the show planned to air for two consecutive cours. The only way to watch the series in the West currently is through the Funimation streaming service. However, this service simulcast Requiem of the Rose King, so it's only available as a subtitled series and not dubbed. However, once the series has finished its run, a dub and physical releases will likely be on the way. Title: Yashahime's Biggest Unanswered Questions After Season 2
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Yashahime Season 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions    Yashahime Season 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions  By Caroline Ramsburg Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Here are some of the most burning questions remaining in Yashahime after the wild conclusion to Season 2.                  The following contains spoilers for Season 2 of Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon, now streaming on Crunchyroll, Funimation, Animelab and Hulu.   With the recent conclusion of Yashahime Season 2, fans have been left with several questions surrounding the Great Dog Demon Family and the original cast of Inuyasha. After the Season 2 finale wrapped up the series' main plot arc with the death of Kirinmaru, the heroes seem happy and free of conflict at last.  While this peaceful and reflective season finale left many wondering if Season 2 will be the end of the entire series, there are still several unanswered questions for Yashahime to hopefully address in future seasons. RELATED: Yashahime Concludes Its Biggest Arc Yet With Death - and Happiness          Does Sesshomaru Love His Daughters?                At the end of Season 2, Towa and Setsuna reunite with their mother Rin to celebrate their recent victory. When Rin gifts her twin daughters fancy fabrics given to them by their father, the twins question his actions and parenting style. They ask Rin why Sesshōmaru didn't help them more when they were growing up -- and when they faced Zero and Kirinmaru.  After calling their father's love for them into question, Rin assures her daughters that he loves them and is relieved that they grew up to become strong on their own. Despite Sesshōmaru displaying tremendous character growth as he operated in the shadows to protect his family, the twins hope to uncover their kuudere father's true feelings. RELATED: The Best Isekai in Which the Main Character Returns Home          How Is Riku Still Alive?                 As the former horn of Kirinmaru, Riku has proven to have several lives in Yashahime. After suffering many fatal and near-fatal injuries, this mysterious character has always managed to return from the grave to shock fans. Toward the very end of Season 2, Riku is killed by Mr. Kirin within the Grim Butterfly. He says a tearful goodbye to Towa and confesses his love for her before seemingly dying for good.  However, when Towa's body is returned to her by Rion, many fans spotted a mysterious horn-shaped figure inside her body. In the Season 2 finale, Riku is resurrected and reappears to explain that he is no longer part of Kirinmaru -- and that he was revived by Rion and Kirinmaru's Kon and Haku. Setsuna questions how this is possible, as do many fans. RELATED: Yashahime Tackles the Morality of Humans and Demons          Why Didn't Sango and Miroku Raise Moroha?                 Since Yashahime began, many fans questioned the noticeable absence of the original Inuyasha cast. Despite Sango and Miroku being alive and well with their own family, they are surprisingly absent from Moroha's life. Kagome and Inuyasha instructed Hachi to take the baby Moroha to the Wolf Demon Tribe for protection instead of entrusting their two best friends with their daughter in their absence.  While they may have chosen Koga and the Wolf Demon Tribe for protection and the strength in numbers, Sango and Miroku have proven their own strength and capabilities time and time again. Not only were Sango and Miroku oddly absent from Moroha's life, but Shippo somehow failed to find Moroha despite her living nearby. RELATED: What Religion Do Anime Monks Like Inyuasha's Miroku Practice?          How Strong Is Shippo Now?                 During the time skip between Inuyasha and Yashahime, it's revealed that Shippo has become a respectable and powerful teacher at a fox-demon school. After spending most of Inuyasha training to become a full-fledged fox demon, he now has the 25th and highest rank in the demon promotions and spends most of his time preparing others for their own exams.  In his first appearance in the sequel, Shippo surprised fans by taking on the form of an elderly fox and a young man before returning to his more familiar younger form. After achieving the highest rank and learning advanced Fox Magic like "Up, Up, and Away", many fans are wondering just how powerful Shippo has become and what tricks he might reveal later in the series. RELATED: Should Moroha Have Been Yashahime's Main Character?          Which Twin is Stronger: Towa or Setsuna?                 Towa and Setsuna sparred several times throughout Yashahime when they were pitted against each other by their enemies or emotional outbursts. Given their unique strengths and weaknesses that cancel each other out, these battles typically ended it stalemates. Since the sisters wield different weapons and inherited different powers from their immensely powerful father, it's incredibly difficult to compare the two. While they are both inarguably strong as the daughters of the Great Beast King of the West, the series has never revealed who would ultimately win in an all-out fight between the two.                   After Its Satisfying Season 2 Finale, Does Yashahime Need a Season 3? Home Video Games Pokémon Cosplayer Finds Beauty in the Franchise's Trash(bag)    Pokémon Cosplayer Finds Beauty in the Franchise's Trash(bag)  By Hayley McCullough Published 16 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Cosplayer Mink the Satyr shows off her incredible Trubbish costume, which transforms the monster's garbage aesthetic into pure elegant fashion.                        A talented fan has transformed the grubby Trash Bag Pokémon, Trubbish, into a creature of pure elegance and beauty.  Popular cosplayer and vtuber Mink the Satyr posted multiple pictures of her Trubbish-inspired costume to Twitter. The beautiful evening gown features delicate lace, billowing sleeves and a full skirt. The cosplayer also uploaded a much more comical version of the costume as an April Fool's joke. RELATED: Electrifying Pokémon Fan Art Reimagines a Legendary Monster as Mech    According to the various Pokédex entries for the monster, Trubbish is a fifth-generation Pokémon and a fusion of garbage bags, industrial waste and chemical agents. It belches toxic gas and has a tendency to follow individuals who litter around. Beyond the games, Trubbish has appeared several times in the greater Pokémon franchise, making minor appearances, for example, in the episodes "Crystal-Clear Sleuthing!" and "Love at First Twirl!" in Pokémon the Series: Sun & Moon.  There have been more recent developments in the Pokémon franchise than just beautiful cosplays. Most notably, two new games -- Pokémon Scarlet and Violet -- are scheduled to debut sometime late this year. These games will introduce fans to the ninth generation of Pokémon and many have already fallen in love with the new starters -- Fucecoco, Sprigatito and Quaxly. Scarlet and Violet will include the open-world gameplay style featured in Pokémon Legends: Arceus and showcase a Spain-inspired setting. RELATED: Study Finds Sonic the Hedgehog Is More Popular Than Pokémon  Moreover, the next batch of episodes for the Pokémon Master Journeys anime series are on their way. While the official premiere date is presently unknown, a teaser trailer and a new poster provide insight into upcoming story beats. These include Ash reuniting with his Greninja, Chloe competing in a contest with her Eevee and Goh encountering the legendary Pokémon Suicune (and possibly Mew as well). Pokémon Master Journeys is the twenty-fourth mainline anime series for the franchise; it premiered on Dec. 11, 2020, in Japan and in the United States on Sept. 10, 2021. An anime based on Pokémon Legends: Arceus has also been announced. While little information about the series has been released, it is expected to premiere online sometime in 2022. Arceus is also getting a special tie-in expansion for the Pokémon Trading Card Game. Astral Radiance will introduce a wealth of cards to the ever-expanding tabletop game and will usher in Radiant Pokémon, a brand-new mechanic. The expansion is scheduled to launch on May 27 and pre-orders are now available.  Several entries in the Pokémon franchise, including Pokémon Master Journeys, can be found and streamed on Netflix. Pokémon Legends: Arceus is now available exclusively for the Nintendo Switch. Her research examines the linguistic structure of storytelling and pop culture. She can often be found marathoning horror movies instead of sleeping, playing puzzle games, and reading a probably unhealthy amount of fanfiction. Title: Sailor Moon Knight Fan Art Is a Marvel-ous Lunar Hero Crossover
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Sailor Moon Knight Fan Art Is the Ultimate Lunar Hero Crossover    Sailor Moon Knight Fan Art Is the Ultimate Lunar Hero Crossover  By Hayley McCullough Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Sailor Moon dons the costume of Marvel's Moon Knight in a new piece of epic mashup fan art that celebrates both the anime and the new Disney+ series.                 One creative superhero fan has merged the magical worlds of Naoko Takeuchi's Sailor Moon and the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Moon Knight, creating "the crossover no one asked for."  The image, which was posted on Twitter by professional production designer Mingjue Helen Chen, depicts Usagi Tsukino/Sailor Moon donning a costume reminiscent of Marc Spector/Moon Knight's super suit. The long, white cape and Usagi's iconic blond hair flutter in the foreground, while a glowing crescent moon features in the background. According to Chen, this fusion is "the only thing I think of when I watch Moon Knight." RELATED: A Decade After Sailor Moon Debuted, Its Director Created a Far Less Popular Sports Anime      Based on the character created by writer Doug Moench and artist Don Perlin, Moon Knight premiered on March 30 and is the sixth television series in the MCU. The show stars Oscar Isaac as the titular hero, who is a mercenary who suffers from dissociative identity disorder. Other members of the case include May Calamawy, Ethan Hawke and Karim El-Hakim. The show's creative team includes writer Jeremy Slater (The Umbrella Academy), cinematographer Andrew Droz Palermo (The Green Knight) and director Mohamed Diab.  Moon Knight's story is heavily rooted in the culture of ancient Egypt, and those involved have made an active effort to stay as historically and mythologically accurate as possible. This careful attention to detail is notable in the wake of Diab's criticism of DC comic book movies, including Wonder Woman 1984, for their inaccurate depictions of the country and its culture. RELATED: Marvel Fans Are Convinced Moon Knight Dropped the MCU's First F-Bomb The original Sailor Moon manga series was published in Kodansha's Nakayoshi magazine from 1991 to 1997, producing 18 volumes worth of content. The story follows high schooler Usagi and her friends as they fight villains and prevent the destruction of the universe as the Sailor Guardians. The manga has a devoted fan following; over 35 million copies of the series have been sold globally.  The Sailor Moon manga was first adapted into an anime by Toei Animation in 1992 and has gone on to inspire a wealth of tie-in books, films, video and tabletop games, stage musicals and even an ice skating show. It has also spawned several theme park attractions; the popular Pretty Guardian Sailor Moon The Miracle 4D: Moon Palace Chapter attraction from 2019 is set to return as part of this year's Universal Cool Japan and will feature an extra scene. The first season of Moon Knight is currently making its debut on Disney+, and various entries in the Sailor Moon franchise are available to stream on Funimation, Crunchyroll, Hulu, Amazon Prime and Netflix. Title: 10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime 10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta    10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta  By CBR Staff Published 11 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   If Goku could pick up on some of the qualities that Vegeta has, Goku could become just as powerful as any God of destruction.                  Goku and Vegeta have been friendly rivals since Dragon Ball Z, but Goku has always been the more relied upon fighter between the two. Goku may currently be the strongest fighter, but Vegeta has been making many strides to keep up with his rival counterpart as the series progresses.  RELATED: 10 Best Things About Goku Under Whis' tutelage paired with their constant encounters with stronger foes, Goku and Vegeta have had their work cut out for them. Whis has mentioned the flaws that each fighter possesses and points out that the two are strongest when fused together. If Goku could pick up on some of the qualities that Vegeta has, Goku could become just as powerful as any God of destruction.  10          Having A Sense Of Pride As A Saiyan                 Part of Goku's charm is that he doesn't carry the same level of pride as his warrior race, the Saiyans. By comparison, Vegeta's greatest asset as the "Prince of all Saiyans" is his incomparable pride of being one.  Goku learning more about the Saiyans' pride may make him a bit more boastful, but finding confidence in being a natural-born warrior may go a long way in his mentality when fighting. This sense of pride may help Goku take fights a bit more seriously.  9          Being A (Better) Role Model For Your Kids                 Fans of Dragon Ball would agree that Goku hasn't necessarily been around for a good portion of Gohan's youth. Whenever Goku showed up, trouble would soon follow. Vegeta on the other hand has grown to become a great parent and is looked up to by both present and future Trunks. RELATED:Dragon Ball Z: 10 Times Goku Put Himself Before His Family  Goku isn't winning any "Father Of The Year" awards compared to Vegeta's level of parenting. Vegeta is shown spending quality time taking care of the kids, and not all time spent with his son Trunks' training.  8          Having Original Attacks                 The Kamehameha and Solar Flare are some of Goku's signature attacks. Sadly, those abilities aren't his original moves. A lot of Goku's moves and abilities were taught to him by teachers he either sought out or ran into. For Goku to be the main protagonist, it's surprising that he doesn't have a move that he has created on his own.  Vegeta has a bunch of special moves, that surprisingly, Goku hasn't taken and made his own. From his famous Galick Gun to Big Bang Attack, Vegeta has mastered many moves that weren't taught to him by Gods or aliens.  7          How To Treat Your Wife                 Why Chi-Chi is still with Goku remains a mystery, but being married to the strongest warrior in the universe must have some perks. However, Vegeta has gone the extra mile and has shown multiple subtle displays of affection to his wife, Bulma, that Goku could take notes on. Vegeta and Bulma may not have started off on the right foot, but Vegeta has shown admiration for his wife's abilities and agitation towards anyone that would bother "his Bulma." Vegeta hasn't spent many years away from his family to train in the afterlife and has taken on babysitting the kids whenever his wife asked.  6          Vegeta's Fashion Sense If these two had to do a popularity contest based on style, Vegeta would win every time. Goku has been wearing the same orange gi since Dragon Ball. Dragon Ball GT finally gave him a new gi color, but the style was lacking compared to Vegeta's. The few times Goku has changed, the clothes wouldn't fit him very well, and he has mentioned that he doesn't feel comfortable in clothes that fit him. Maybe give credit to Bulma for Vegeta's trendy clothes, but Vegeta's style doesn't mind taking risks. Remember when Vegeta had a mustache?  5          Showing Respect To Higher Beings                 Goku has been on the verge of ending many lives by just being the whimsical martial artist he is. For someone that can read power levels and sense ki energy, Goku usually lacks formality towards gods and other higher beings that can easily wipe away existences. Vegeta, who is aware of the statuses and legends of these beings, always rolls out the red carpet. RELATED: 10 Times Goku Was Put In His Place In Dragon Ball Although his pride usually overshadows his judgment, Vegeta knows when to be quiet and respectful toward those higher in power. Especially when that power can wipe away or restore a universe. Vegeta provides many meals for Beerus and Whis just to keep the earth safe.  4          Taking Fights More Seriously                 Fans all know the feeling when the Z warriors are about to defeat the enemy, but Goku lets them power up again to turn the tide. Goku never takes his fights seriously until someone dies. He even played around with the likes of Kid Buu's destructive tendencies just to see the extent of his power. Vegeta was a victim of this mentality in the Cell Saga and dearly paid for it. Fast-forward to Vegeta's training with Whis, he has learned to fight at full power regardless of what level his opponent is. Goku has even been told by Whis that he would be stronger if he fought more seriously.  3          Know That All Evil Can't Be Redeemed                 Throughout the series, Goku has met a lot of opponents that later became friends or rivals. Most of his current friends were once conflicts that Goku has to deal with. However, there are some characters that are too evil to be kept alive and have no hope of turning over a new leaf. Vegeta is the opposite and will end an opponent's life without hesitation. Maybe if Goku had Vegeta's standards on what is evil, the majority of Dragon Ball's villains wouldn't be later threats or still trying to destroy the earth.  2          Utilizing Battle Tactics                 Whenever Goku gets into a fight, it's rare to see him thinking with his head. He fights instinctively and doesn't have much of a plan when facing tough opponents. Thanks to his friends and allies, Goku has managed to prevail over foes, but maybe fighting an opponent one-on-one isn't the best idea.  RELATED: 10 Things Goku Learned From Whis Goku could learn to fire a ki blast whenever an enemy has their back turned to him. Vegeta was the difference for shooting Cell in the back when Gohan was struggling against him. It's not fighting dirty, just strategy by catching your opponent by surprise.  1          Goku Can Learn To Be More Careful In Battles                 In Dragon Ball Super, Whis has pointed out Goku's weakness: he's too careless. Though some may describe Goku as more of a clear-headed individual, Vegeta is more of a careful and tactical fighter. Goku could benefit from Vegeta's way of thinking.  Goku letting opponents reach full power or thinking they will turn over a new leaf has gotten him and his friends into a lot of trouble. Vegeta didn't give a second thought to destroying Cooler, Frieza's brother. Maybe Goku should reconsider Frieza's threat level since his potential is so high. Title: 10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta
Data: Home Anime 10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta    10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta  By CBR Staff Published 11 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   If Goku could pick up on some of the qualities that Vegeta has, Goku could become just as powerful as any God of destruction.                  Goku and Vegeta have been friendly rivals since Dragon Ball Z, but Goku has always been the more relied upon fighter between the two. Goku may currently be the strongest fighter, but Vegeta has been making many strides to keep up with his rival counterpart as the series progresses.  RELATED: 10 Best Things About Goku Under Whis' tutelage paired with their constant encounters with stronger foes, Goku and Vegeta have had their work cut out for them. Whis has mentioned the flaws that each fighter possesses and points out that the two are strongest when fused together. If Goku could pick up on some of the qualities that Vegeta has, Goku could become just as powerful as any God of destruction.  10          Having A Sense Of Pride As A Saiyan                 Part of Goku's charm is that he doesn't carry the same level of pride as his warrior race, the Saiyans. By comparison, Vegeta's greatest asset as the "Prince of all Saiyans" is his incomparable pride of being one.  Goku learning more about the Saiyans' pride may make him a bit more boastful, but finding confidence in being a natural-born warrior may go a long way in his mentality when fighting. This sense of pride may help Goku take fights a bit more seriously.  9          Being A (Better) Role Model For Your Kids                 Fans of Dragon Ball would agree that Goku hasn't necessarily been around for a good portion of Gohan's youth. Whenever Goku showed up, trouble would soon follow. Vegeta on the other hand has grown to become a great parent and is looked up to by both present and future Trunks. RELATED:Dragon Ball Z: 10 Times Goku Put Himself Before His Family  Goku isn't winning any "Father Of The Year" awards compared to Vegeta's level of parenting. Vegeta is shown spending quality time taking care of the kids, and not all time spent with his son Trunks' training.  8          Having Original Attacks                 The Kamehameha and Solar Flare are some of Goku's signature attacks. Sadly, those abilities aren't his original moves. A lot of Goku's moves and abilities were taught to him by teachers he either sought out or ran into. For Goku to be the main protagonist, it's surprising that he doesn't have a move that he has created on his own.  Vegeta has a bunch of special moves, that surprisingly, Goku hasn't taken and made his own. From his famous Galick Gun to Big Bang Attack, Vegeta has mastered many moves that weren't taught to him by Gods or aliens.  7          How To Treat Your Wife                 Why Chi-Chi is still with Goku remains a mystery, but being married to the strongest warrior in the universe must have some perks. However, Vegeta has gone the extra mile and has shown multiple subtle displays of affection to his wife, Bulma, that Goku could take notes on. Vegeta and Bulma may not have started off on the right foot, but Vegeta has shown admiration for his wife's abilities and agitation towards anyone that would bother "his Bulma." Vegeta hasn't spent many years away from his family to train in the afterlife and has taken on babysitting the kids whenever his wife asked.  6          Vegeta's Fashion Sense If these two had to do a popularity contest based on style, Vegeta would win every time. Goku has been wearing the same orange gi since Dragon Ball. Dragon Ball GT finally gave him a new gi color, but the style was lacking compared to Vegeta's. The few times Goku has changed, the clothes wouldn't fit him very well, and he has mentioned that he doesn't feel comfortable in clothes that fit him. Maybe give credit to Bulma for Vegeta's trendy clothes, but Vegeta's style doesn't mind taking risks. Remember when Vegeta had a mustache?  5          Showing Respect To Higher Beings                 Goku has been on the verge of ending many lives by just being the whimsical martial artist he is. For someone that can read power levels and sense ki energy, Goku usually lacks formality towards gods and other higher beings that can easily wipe away existences. Vegeta, who is aware of the statuses and legends of these beings, always rolls out the red carpet. RELATED: 10 Times Goku Was Put In His Place In Dragon Ball Although his pride usually overshadows his judgment, Vegeta knows when to be quiet and respectful toward those higher in power. Especially when that power can wipe away or restore a universe. Vegeta provides many meals for Beerus and Whis just to keep the earth safe.  4          Taking Fights More Seriously                 Fans all know the feeling when the Z warriors are about to defeat the enemy, but Goku lets them power up again to turn the tide. Goku never takes his fights seriously until someone dies. He even played around with the likes of Kid Buu's destructive tendencies just to see the extent of his power. Vegeta was a victim of this mentality in the Cell Saga and dearly paid for it. Fast-forward to Vegeta's training with Whis, he has learned to fight at full power regardless of what level his opponent is. Goku has even been told by Whis that he would be stronger if he fought more seriously.  3          Know That All Evil Can't Be Redeemed                 Throughout the series, Goku has met a lot of opponents that later became friends or rivals. Most of his current friends were once conflicts that Goku has to deal with. However, there are some characters that are too evil to be kept alive and have no hope of turning over a new leaf. Vegeta is the opposite and will end an opponent's life without hesitation. Maybe if Goku had Vegeta's standards on what is evil, the majority of Dragon Ball's villains wouldn't be later threats or still trying to destroy the earth.  2          Utilizing Battle Tactics                 Whenever Goku gets into a fight, it's rare to see him thinking with his head. He fights instinctively and doesn't have much of a plan when facing tough opponents. Thanks to his friends and allies, Goku has managed to prevail over foes, but maybe fighting an opponent one-on-one isn't the best idea.  RELATED: 10 Things Goku Learned From Whis Goku could learn to fire a ki blast whenever an enemy has their back turned to him. Vegeta was the difference for shooting Cell in the back when Gohan was struggling against him. It's not fighting dirty, just strategy by catching your opponent by surprise.  1          Goku Can Learn To Be More Careful In Battles                 In Dragon Ball Super, Whis has pointed out Goku's weakness: he's too careless. Though some may describe Goku as more of a clear-headed individual, Vegeta is more of a careful and tactical fighter. Goku could benefit from Vegeta's way of thinking.  Goku letting opponents reach full power or thinking they will turn over a new leaf has gotten him and his friends into a lot of trouble. Vegeta didn't give a second thought to destroying Cooler, Frieza's brother. Maybe Goku should reconsider Frieza's threat level since his potential is so high. Title: One Piece's Earlier Arcs Prove Luffy Is the Best Devil Fruit User
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime How One Piece's Earlier Arcs Prove Luffy Is the Best User of His Devil Fruit    How One Piece's Earlier Arcs Prove Luffy Is the Best User of His Devil Fruit  By Christian Markle Published 15 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   One Piece's Luffy has always been a free soul doing whatever he wishes. His earliest exploits prove why he's the perfect user of his Devil Fruit.                  The following contains spoilers for the One Piece manga, available in English from Viz Media.   One Piece is once again causing uproar after revealing the truth behind Monkey D. Luffy's Devil Fruit. The one he stole from Shanks during his childhood years has always been thought to be the Gum-Gum Fruit, which gives his body its rubber properties. Throughout the series' long tenure, fans have taken it as a fact since Luffy's abilities check out with the Devil Fruit's description.  In recent chapters of the manga, however, One Piece reveals that Luffy's Devil Fruit is in fact not the Gomu Gomu no Mi but Hito Hito no Mi: Model, Nika. It made its debut when Kaido knocked Luffy out after a long battle, awakening his Devil Fruit abilities. Luffy's Gear Five, which is also believed to be his Devil Fruit awakening, allowed him to execute powerful attacks that are reminiscent of his earlier adventuring days. RELATED: One Piece Characters That Deserve Their Own Series                               Hito Hito no Mi: Model, Nika is modeled on the mythical warrior whom slaves venerated as the Sun God. He was said to be the one who will free them from oppression, but the more notable aspect of this Devil Fruit is the power it grants its user. The Five Elders have even described it as the most ridiculous power in the world, only being limited by the wielder's imagination. Luffy has shown this repeatedly during his most recent fight with Kaido. His attacks have become more outrageous after activating his Gear Five, often applying the properties of rubber not only on himself, but also to his environment and on the other characters.  Even though his attacks are mostly similar to what he usually uses, the effects vary greatly. When Kaido swallowed Luffy, the latter ballooned inside the Emperor's stomach. He also used Kaido's nose as leverage by extending his hands through the dragon's eyes. When Kaido hit Luffy's head with his club, it flattened in the form of the club's surface and remained that way for a bit -- and these are only a few examples of how ridiculous Luffy's power can be. RELATED: Everything We Know About One Piece's Ancient Weapons, the Strongest of Them All                               While Luffy's recent offensive creations have put smiles on One Piece readers' faces, they aren't necessarily surprising. Luffy has a long history of inventing unique and outrageous attacks. He used to be more experimental with his power, often creating at least one comical technique per arc.  During his battle against Crocodile, Luffy expanded his head and attempted to eat the Warlord after realizing none of his attacks were dealing any damage. Similarly, he stole some of Arlong's teeth and used them to bite the Fish-man. These attacks, however, have dwindled after the time skip as One Piece has taken a more serious tone. Nika's revelation brings the series back to its comical root as all of Luffy's absurdity cascades out while in his Gear Five form. Perhaps one attack that will be remembered for years to come is when he used Kaido's dragon form as a jump rope. With bigger wars brewing in One Piece, fans will likely be seeing more of Luffy's greatly-missed inventive genius.                   One Piece Theory: Luffy's Devil Fruit Isn't the Gomu Gomu no Mi  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime one piece     About The Author      Christian Markle                                     (106 Articles Published)     Christian Markle is writing manga-related articles for CBR. If he's gripping his hair writing an article, he's inside his hole indulging in manga, anime, and/or video games. His favorite manga is One Piece, which the ever-lost Zoro is undeniably the best. Title: Dallas Marshall | CBR
Data: Dallas Marshall    Dallas Marshall is a long-time cook, writer, published author, and all-around eccentric. He got into the whole anime mess at the age of ten when he discovered the wild world of Pokemon and has not looked back since.   He is the author of the book, Anime Adrenaline! which can be found on Amazon.com as well as a writer for the website Film Inquiry. News outlets have also stated that Dallas sightings have been reported at book stores where he can be found lurking in the horror and used manga sections. + Read More Articles Published : 54                            Anime   Sakamoto Days Feels Like It Comes From the '90s - and That's a Good Thing  Sakamoto Days has the feel of a manga from the '90s which may be off-putting to some, but there's more than enough hijinks and action to draw in fans.  19 hours ago                       Anime   The Director of Escaflowne Was Also Behind This Old-School Sci-Fi Crime Anime  Escaflowne is considered a classic anime. Title: Attack on Titan's Season 4, Part 2 Finale Parallels Episode 1
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Attack on Titan Season 4 Finale Tragically Parallels Episode 1    Attack on Titan Season 4 Finale Tragically Parallels Episode 1  By Nerissa Rupnarine Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The Season 4, Part 2 finale of Attack on Titan ends with major destruction - and a haunting callback to the fall of Shiganshina that started it all.                  The following contains spoilers for Attack on Titan Season 4, Episode 28 "The Dawn of Humanity", now streaming on Crunchyroll, Funimation and Hulu.   The Attack on Titan Season 4, Part 2 finale ends on a haunting cliffhanger by bringing forth the Rumbling's promised devastation as Eren Jaeger -- in the form of the Founding Titan -- and the wall titans finally reach the continent of Marley, signaling the beginning of a mass genocide.  Since Eren started the Rumbling several episodes back, both Eldians and Marleyans have scrambled for a way to cease the inevitable. However, Hange Zoe had made it clear they wouldn't be able to stop Eren completely. In other words, while the heroes are fighting to the best of their abilities to save the world, at the very least, a portion of the Rumbling will be carried out successfully -- and audiences can see it's only breeding fear and death. The sight of Eren's absurdly large Founding Titan leading the charge is horrific but familiar, paralleling the Colossal Titan's initial attack against Shiganshina back in Episode 1.  Related: Attack on Titan: Eren Lied to Mikasa                                The fall of Shiganshina was not only the inciting incident to kickstart Attack on Titan, but it also lit an unrelenting flame inside Eren that took his character journey to new territories. Back then, Bertholdt Hoover used the powers of the Colossal Titan to break through the gates of Shiganshina, allowing for any lurking titans to invade. Countless people lost their lives, including Eren's mother Carla, who was eaten alive before his very eyes. Grief-stricken and completely outraged, Eren declared that he will "kill them all". In this context, "them" referred to the Titans and he continues to carry a deep-seeded hatred for them -- but as the series progresses and mysteries are unraveled, Eren's goal to wipe out "every single one" now refers to humans rather than Titans.  In the present, Eren has become what he hates most and the irony is nothing short of tragic. Now, his earlier declaration holds new meaning. As it turns out, Titans are merely Eldians -- humans transformed into a monstrous species against their will. The main conflict in Attack on Titan isn't simply mankind vs. titans, but mankind vs. mankind. Eren wants peace for his people, but 2000 years of fighting and xenophobia makes this complicated. As children, Eren, Mikasa Ackerman and Armin Arlert used to dream of a world beyond the walls, with the idea of freedom propelling them forward despite the hardships that awaited them as military personnel. The reality is that past the walls awaited more enemies. This realization was detrimental to them all, but it was Eren who took things a bit too far. Fueled by the memory of his mother's death, Eren initiates the Rumbling to eliminate all of humanity except those on Paradis Island.  Related: Attack on Titan: Floch Wasn't the Only One Eren Told About His Plan                 While the Rumbling is certainly a parallel to the series' start, it's also far more devastating. Instead of one Colossal Titan letting in a tirade of pure Titans to destroy a portion of Paradis Island, Eren leads the charge among an army of Colossal Titans with the intent of destroying the world. While the Marleyans fire off heavy artillery, it quickly proves to be insufficient. Surprisingly, the Wall Titans can swim -- and they swim much faster than they walk. While people aren't being devoured like they were in Episode 1, it's still a slaughter. Soldiers are blown away by pressurized air or melted by the steam exerted by the Titans. The Part 2 finale ends with a shot of a Colossal Titan stepping on the camera, likely implying the fate of the soldiers currently running for their lives. Additionally, like Carla and the victims of Shiganshina, they are dying for reasons they don't fully understand. If that's not enough, the music playing during Eren's attack is a rendition of that which played in Episode 1.  Eren's current belief system in Attack on Titan is twisted, but it's hard to ignore the fact that his beliefs were created by being a victim of circumstance. After first discovering his ability to wield the Attack Titan back in Season 1, Eren wanted to be humanity's hope. But things have changed. The world isn't what he thought it was and by becoming the very thing he once swore to destroy, Eren becomes the world's enemy in the hopes of protecting the people he loves.                  Attack on Titan: The Final Season Part 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime Attack on Titan     About The Author   Nerissa Rupnarine                                     (125 Articles Published)     Nerissa Rupnarine is a writer, reader and anime fan obsessed with all types of storytelling and is always looking to share her passion with others. She is a Marketing graduate and is currently studying Screenwriting for Film and Television at the Toronto Film School. Title: Attack on Titan's Season 4, Part 2 Finale Parallels Episode 1
Data: Home Anime Attack on Titan Season 4 Finale Tragically Parallels Episode 1    Attack on Titan Season 4 Finale Tragically Parallels Episode 1  By Nerissa Rupnarine Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The Season 4, Part 2 finale of Attack on Titan ends with major destruction - and a haunting callback to the fall of Shiganshina that started it all.                  The following contains spoilers for Attack on Titan Season 4, Episode 28 "The Dawn of Humanity", now streaming on Crunchyroll, Funimation and Hulu.   The Attack on Titan Season 4, Part 2 finale ends on a haunting cliffhanger by bringing forth the Rumbling's promised devastation as Eren Jaeger -- in the form of the Founding Titan -- and the wall titans finally reach the continent of Marley, signaling the beginning of a mass genocide.  Since Eren started the Rumbling several episodes back, both Eldians and Marleyans have scrambled for a way to cease the inevitable. However, Hange Zoe had made it clear they wouldn't be able to stop Eren completely. In other words, while the heroes are fighting to the best of their abilities to save the world, at the very least, a portion of the Rumbling will be carried out successfully -- and audiences can see it's only breeding fear and death. The sight of Eren's absurdly large Founding Titan leading the charge is horrific but familiar, paralleling the Colossal Titan's initial attack against Shiganshina back in Episode 1.  Related: Attack on Titan: Eren Lied to Mikasa                                The fall of Shiganshina was not only the inciting incident to kickstart Attack on Titan, but it also lit an unrelenting flame inside Eren that took his character journey to new territories. Back then, Bertholdt Hoover used the powers of the Colossal Titan to break through the gates of Shiganshina, allowing for any lurking titans to invade. Countless people lost their lives, including Eren's mother Carla, who was eaten alive before his very eyes. Grief-stricken and completely outraged, Eren declared that he will "kill them all". In this context, "them" referred to the Titans and he continues to carry a deep-seeded hatred for them -- but as the series progresses and mysteries are unraveled, Eren's goal to wipe out "every single one" now refers to humans rather than Titans.  In the present, Eren has become what he hates most and the irony is nothing short of tragic. Now, his earlier declaration holds new meaning. As it turns out, Titans are merely Eldians -- humans transformed into a monstrous species against their will. The main conflict in Attack on Titan isn't simply mankind vs. titans, but mankind vs. mankind. Eren wants peace for his people, but 2000 years of fighting and xenophobia makes this complicated. As children, Eren, Mikasa Ackerman and Armin Arlert used to dream of a world beyond the walls, with the idea of freedom propelling them forward despite the hardships that awaited them as military personnel. The reality is that past the walls awaited more enemies. This realization was detrimental to them all, but it was Eren who took things a bit too far. Fueled by the memory of his mother's death, Eren initiates the Rumbling to eliminate all of humanity except those on Paradis Island.  Related: Attack on Titan: Floch Wasn't the Only One Eren Told About His Plan                 While the Rumbling is certainly a parallel to the series' start, it's also far more devastating. Instead of one Colossal Titan letting in a tirade of pure Titans to destroy a portion of Paradis Island, Eren leads the charge among an army of Colossal Titans with the intent of destroying the world. While the Marleyans fire off heavy artillery, it quickly proves to be insufficient. Surprisingly, the Wall Titans can swim -- and they swim much faster than they walk. While people aren't being devoured like they were in Episode 1, it's still a slaughter. Soldiers are blown away by pressurized air or melted by the steam exerted by the Titans. The Part 2 finale ends with a shot of a Colossal Titan stepping on the camera, likely implying the fate of the soldiers currently running for their lives. Additionally, like Carla and the victims of Shiganshina, they are dying for reasons they don't fully understand. If that's not enough, the music playing during Eren's attack is a rendition of that which played in Episode 1.  Eren's current belief system in Attack on Titan is twisted, but it's hard to ignore the fact that his beliefs were created by being a victim of circumstance. After first discovering his ability to wield the Attack Titan back in Season 1, Eren wanted to be humanity's hope. But things have changed. The world isn't what he thought it was and by becoming the very thing he once swore to destroy, Eren becomes the world's enemy in the hopes of protecting the people he loves. Title: Attack on Titan: Mikasa and Annie Debate Killing Eren in Exclusive Final Season Clip
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Attack on Titan: Mikasa and Annie Debate Killing Eren in Exclusive Final Season Clip    Attack on Titan: Mikasa and Annie Debate Killing Eren in Exclusive Final Season Clip  By Michael Lacerna Published 19 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Annie and Mikasa argue over Eren's fate in an exclusive new English-dubbed clip from Attack on Titan: The Final Season - Part 2.                 In a new exclusive clip from the English dub of Attack on Titan: The Final Season - Part 2, Mikasa and Annie question each other's loyalty to Paradis and to Eren.  SPOILERS FOR ATTACK ON TITAN: THE FINAL SEASON - PART 2 FOLLOW: The new clip comes from Episode 84 of the popular dark-fantasy series, which will be available on Crunchyroll on April 10. In the new preview, Annie questions Mikasa, Armin and Connie's ability to fight their former friend and ally, Eren Jaeger. The questioning gets especially heated when Annie pushes Mikasa on her feelings for the series' hero-turned-villain, which causes Mikasa to draw her swords as Annie prepares to transform into her titan form. RELATED: Attack on Titan Reveals the Moment That Solidified Eren's Genocidal Plans    After weeks of speculation from fans, the producers of Attack on Titan confirmed that the show will continue with The Final Season's third act in 2023. The announcement that Part 3 was in production was made after the 12th and final episode of Part 2 was broadcast on April 3. Part 3 will once again be produced by studio MAPPA, who took over production of the series after Wit Studio (Ranking of Kings, Spy x Family) animated the series' first three seasons. While the subtitled simulcast of the season has concluded, Crunchyroll's simuldub of Part 2 is still on-going. Fans who prefer the dubbed version of the series can also watch it on Adult Swim's Toonami programming block. The show was added to the network's late-night schedule earlier this year, alongside other critically acclaimed anime such as Made in Abyss and Assassination Classroom.  RELATED: Attack on Titan Brings Back a Fan Favorite Attack on Titan was created by Hajime Isayama and first published in 2009. The original manga was a massive commercial success, achieving a worldwide circulation of over 100 million copies. The series has also been a similar hit with critics, who have lauded the series for its tense storytelling and memorable cast of characters. The final chapter of the manga was released in 2021, and despite an extremely divisive reaction to the finale, the anime adaptation of the series continues to be one of the most popular shows in the world, with one market analyst firm naming The Final Season "the most in-demand" show of 2021.  In addition to the current season, all previous seasons of the anime are available for streaming on Crunchyroll. Isayama's complete manga series is available in English from Kodansha USA. After working for several years as a writer and copy editor for companies like an advertising agency and a music label, Michael has come to CBR to pursue his true passion: sharing his love for giant robots and collectible monsters. Title: Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody Elder Millennial Angst
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime How Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody the Elder Millennial Psyche    How Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody the Elder Millennial Psyche  By Olufolahan Olowoyeye Published 23 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Drawing their convictions from alienation and resentment, Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami describe the experience of many elder Millennials.                 Two of the most celebrated elements of Gege Akutami's Jujutsu Kaisen are its nuanced approach to character development and its heavy inspiration from contemporary culture. While the series frequently employs antipathy as a method of character development, instances of convergence in their motivations illustrate another method. This alternative approach is shown by the characters Gojo and Nanami, who, though differing wildly in appearance, behavior and histories, share certain generational quirks reminiscent of elder Millennials.  However, in line with the principal theme of Jujutsu Kaisen -- which illustrates the fundamental role of harnessing negativity in human life and culture -- what brings Gojo and Nanami together is less how they feel, but rather what they ultimately decide to do. In learning to draw conviction from alienation, disillusionment and resentment, Gojo and Nanami together describe a collective arc grounded in Millennial angst. RELATED: How Antipathy Drives Character Development in Jujutsu Kaisen          Kento Nanami: The Shaman Who Overcame His Resignation                 When Kento Nanami leaves Jujutsu sorcery for a traditional corporate job, two realizations follow: a life resigned to the empty pursuit of money stays empty, and that the little asked of workers in his position -- to perpetuate the inequality and absurdity of modern life -- is not enough to live on. The cognitive dissonance of these realizations comes to a head in a bakery where he has a negative epiphany familiar to many Millennials: he doesn’t have to do anything. In essence, like many others in his position, Nanami doesn’t have to make the world better, or do anything of any “real” value; instead, he is only incentivized to perpetuate the same absurdity and despair that feeds curses.  His decision becomes clear: seeing the curse perched on the young woman’s shoulder, he could simply leave her to his fate. His sandwich is already paid for, so their business is over. Any surplus effort he invests is at his own cost. Until this moment, that was a source of despair for Nanami; by choosing to act instead, he renews his conviction and returns to his work. RELATED: Jujutsu Kaisen 0 Delivers a Thrilling & Emotional Prequel That Fans Will Love          Satoru Gojo's Main Character Syndrome                 Contrary to Nanami's gradual alienation in the workplace, Gojo's conviction in Jujutsu Kaisen stems from his personal experience of trauma and betrayal. Reeling from the shock and loss of his experiences with Geto and Yuta in Jujutsu High, Gojo transforms his own emptiness and resentment into a limitless thirst for personal power. While his ambition is in part motivated by a desire to give children like Yuta and Yuji the carefree childhood he lacked, his contempt for the elites of Jujutsu Sorcery adds another layer.  Like Nanami, dissatisfaction with the status quo has led Gojo to lose faith in the leadership and guidance of the previous generation. But unlike Nanami, this disillusionment is abrupt, traumatic and deeply personal, versus the more subtle and protracted disillusionment of working life. Similarly, just as Nanami's dry, straight-laced professionalism contrasts with his deep feeling, Gojo's own laid-back attitude contrasts with his profound megalomania. RELATED: Jujutsu Kaisen Shows What Happens When Three Domain Expansions Overlap Over the course of Jujutsu Kaisen, Gojo's antipathy for his superiors in Jujutsu sorcery -- illustrated by his blatant disrespect for Principal Yorinobu and others -- supplies critical context for his thirst for power and his arrogance. For Gojo, "being the strongest" is a role to which only he is truly "fit," in that he can generate and sustain the conviction to do so. Like Nanami, this conviction takes root in alienation and disillusionment with the powers-that-be, but with an important distinction. While Nanami critiques the inhuman priorities of these powers, the source of Gojo's own grievances is their relative weakness.  Though Jujutsu Kaisen's manga and its adaptations alike work to distinguish these characters, their worldviews nevertheless converge in an unsettling, generational intuition: the world is deeply broken, those in charge of it have largely failed, and whatever responsibility to do differently rests solely in one's self.                  Jujutsu Kaisen 0's Maki Echoes Fruits Basket's Most Tragic Love Interest  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime jujutsu kaisen     About The Author      Olufolahan Olowoyeye                                     (27 Articles Published)     Folahan grew up in rural California, where empty space and open sky gifted him with plenty of free time and an overactive imagination.  This combination led him to graduate school in Comparative Literature, and in time, back to his first loves--science fiction, fantasy, and of course, anime.  In addition to these pursuits, Folahan also enjoys jujutsu, swimming, aviation, and cooking. Title: Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody Elder Millennial Angst
Data: Home Anime How Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody the Elder Millennial Psyche    How Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody the Elder Millennial Psyche  By Olufolahan Olowoyeye Published 23 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Drawing their convictions from alienation and resentment, Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami describe the experience of many elder Millennials.                 Two of the most celebrated elements of Gege Akutami's Jujutsu Kaisen are its nuanced approach to character development and its heavy inspiration from contemporary culture. While the series frequently employs antipathy as a method of character development, instances of convergence in their motivations illustrate another method. This alternative approach is shown by the characters Gojo and Nanami, who, though differing wildly in appearance, behavior and histories, share certain generational quirks reminiscent of elder Millennials.  However, in line with the principal theme of Jujutsu Kaisen -- which illustrates the fundamental role of harnessing negativity in human life and culture -- what brings Gojo and Nanami together is less how they feel, but rather what they ultimately decide to do. In learning to draw conviction from alienation, disillusionment and resentment, Gojo and Nanami together describe a collective arc grounded in Millennial angst. RELATED: How Antipathy Drives Character Development in Jujutsu Kaisen          Kento Nanami: The Shaman Who Overcame His Resignation                 When Kento Nanami leaves Jujutsu sorcery for a traditional corporate job, two realizations follow: a life resigned to the empty pursuit of money stays empty, and that the little asked of workers in his position -- to perpetuate the inequality and absurdity of modern life -- is not enough to live on. The cognitive dissonance of these realizations comes to a head in a bakery where he has a negative epiphany familiar to many Millennials: he doesn’t have to do anything. In essence, like many others in his position, Nanami doesn’t have to make the world better, or do anything of any “real” value; instead, he is only incentivized to perpetuate the same absurdity and despair that feeds curses.  His decision becomes clear: seeing the curse perched on the young woman’s shoulder, he could simply leave her to his fate. His sandwich is already paid for, so their business is over. Any surplus effort he invests is at his own cost. Until this moment, that was a source of despair for Nanami; by choosing to act instead, he renews his conviction and returns to his work. RELATED: Jujutsu Kaisen 0 Delivers a Thrilling & Emotional Prequel That Fans Will Love          Satoru Gojo's Main Character Syndrome                 Contrary to Nanami's gradual alienation in the workplace, Gojo's conviction in Jujutsu Kaisen stems from his personal experience of trauma and betrayal. Reeling from the shock and loss of his experiences with Geto and Yuta in Jujutsu High, Gojo transforms his own emptiness and resentment into a limitless thirst for personal power. While his ambition is in part motivated by a desire to give children like Yuta and Yuji the carefree childhood he lacked, his contempt for the elites of Jujutsu Sorcery adds another layer.  Like Nanami, dissatisfaction with the status quo has led Gojo to lose faith in the leadership and guidance of the previous generation. But unlike Nanami, this disillusionment is abrupt, traumatic and deeply personal, versus the more subtle and protracted disillusionment of working life. Similarly, just as Nanami's dry, straight-laced professionalism contrasts with his deep feeling, Gojo's own laid-back attitude contrasts with his profound megalomania. RELATED: Jujutsu Kaisen Shows What Happens When Three Domain Expansions Overlap Over the course of Jujutsu Kaisen, Gojo's antipathy for his superiors in Jujutsu sorcery -- illustrated by his blatant disrespect for Principal Yorinobu and others -- supplies critical context for his thirst for power and his arrogance. For Gojo, "being the strongest" is a role to which only he is truly "fit," in that he can generate and sustain the conviction to do so. Like Nanami, this conviction takes root in alienation and disillusionment with the powers-that-be, but with an important distinction. While Nanami critiques the inhuman priorities of these powers, the source of Gojo's own grievances is their relative weakness.  Though Jujutsu Kaisen's manga and its adaptations alike work to distinguish these characters, their worldviews nevertheless converge in an unsettling, generational intuition: the world is deeply broken, those in charge of it have largely failed, and whatever responsibility to do differently rests solely in one's self. This combination led him to graduate school in Comparative Literature, and in time, back to his first loves--science fiction, fantasy, and of course, anime.  In addition to these pursuits, Folahan also enjoys jujutsu, swimming, aviation, and cooking. Title: One-Punch Man: Garo's Ultimate Goal Clarifies His Allegiance
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime One-Punch Man Clarifies Garo's Allegiance    One-Punch Man Clarifies Garo's Allegiance  By Christian Markle Published 13 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   One-Punch Man's recent releases seem to hint at Garo's change of allegiance. Chapter 159 clarifies what he really wants to achieve.                  The following contains spoilers for One-Punch Man Chapter 159, "Source of Anxiety," by One, Yusuke Murata, John Werry and James Gaubatz, available in English at Viz Media.   One-Punch Man isn't lacking in characters with interesting power, fighting style or personality. However, not many of them offer depth. Most are simply there for the sake of entertainment, either as a gag or some form of mockery. Garo is one of the few who actually has a story to tell with a respectable background arc -- though his motivations are questionable.  When Garo made his debut, he announced he was siding with the monsters. He claimed to sympathize with the villains and vowed to destroy the heroes. However, his power was still lacking then so he sought to fight stronger opponents to hone himself and his skills. He challenged S-Class heroes and even hospitalized some of them, but he also defeated countless strong monsters and had wholesome moments along the way. One-Punch Man Chapter 159 finally clarifies whether Garo stands on the side of good or evil. RELATED: One-Punch Man: Saitama Just Pulled a Jimbei Move                After Centisennin and Evil Ocean Water were dealt with, Saitama went toward Garo and asked the Hero Hunter what exactly he is. But before he arrived, Garo recalled that the S-Class heroes were knocked out and yet to reappear. He assumed they were out of commission, supposedly meaning he no longer had anything to fear. Garo could finally perfect absolute evil using the martial art form he created. Despite this, he instead felt that there was something he was missing -- then Saitama arrived.  Garo did not recognize Saitama despite having met the bald hero a couple of times previously in One-Punch Man. He took a moment to think about Saitama's question, casting away his master's advice to follow his heart. Resolving himself to accomplish the task that he believed only he could do, he introduced himself as the monster Garo, then followed by claiming to cast all of humanity into the depths of despair and become the absolute evil. RELATED: One-Punch Man: A Dark & Twisted Backstory Led to Genos Becoming a Cyborg                Garo's decision isn't surprising, as he's always been dead set on pursuing the evil path. In fact, it's his primary motivation to get stronger. It's just that One-Punch Man has made it seem that Garo was finally turning over a new leaf. He painstakingly protected the kid Tareo on multiple occasions and even joined hands with Metal Bat -- someone he had a bad history with -- in order to defeat Centisennin. Garo also had some sort of enlightenment after going head-to-head against his former master, which allowed him to regain his humanity.  With Garo cementing his goal to be the ultimate evil, it's probably safe to assume that the only means to make him change his mind is to utterly destroy him. Fortunately, the most capable individual for that job is already on the scene. Title: Platinum End's Most Shocking Plot Twists
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Platinum End's 5 Most Shocking Plot Twists & How They Defined the Story    Platinum End's 5 Most Shocking Plot Twists & How They Defined the Story  By Louis Kemner Published 21 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Platinum End is a mind-bending thriller anime with godhood itself on the line, and the story featured many intense twists and turns.                  The following contains spoilers for Platinum End, now streaming on Crunchyroll and Funimation, as well as dicsussion of suicide.   Platinum End, a thriller anime by the same creators as Death Note, stars the humble, pacifistic Kakehashi Mirai who aims to simply live a life of ordinary happiness -- and his efforts to win a divine battle royale to decide who will become the world's next God. It takes more than angel wings and red arrows to win this fight.  The story of Platinum End began as a fairly routine battle royale scenario with an angelic theme but soon expanded in scope and explored a variety of intriguing themes about the purpose of life, the cost of taking another life, the meaning of what God really is and far more. And these topics are explored in more than a few wild and unpredictable plot twists along the way. RELATED: Platinum End's Mirai is a Weak Protagonist - and It's Harming the Story          When Nasse Chose Mirai As A God Candidate                 The very first plot twist in Platinum End ranks among the most important. In fact, if it didn't take place, Mirai wouldn't have even been alive to witness the rest of the series. After graduating from middle school, the miserable Mirai was ready to end his own life and attempted to do so by falling off a skyscraper. That was when the playful but brutal angel Nasse literally swooped in to save his life, and Mirai vowed to make the most of what she did for him.  He was then chosen as one of the 13 God candidates who would fight over the throne of Heaven, launching the entire rest of Platinum End. From this point on, Mirai would fight to protect his own life and that of the people around him. Never again will he consider the self-destructive path. RELATED: Platinum End: Was It Muni Who Plotted to [SPOILER] Heaven?          When Mirai's Team Defeated Metropoliman                 Mirai's most powerful rival, the armored would-be hero Metropoliman, was poised to win the entire battle royale with his advanced arrow techniques and devious methods. This included sending his minion Hajime to take Mukaido Nanato's wife and daughter hostage. During the battle, Mirai and Saki finally turned the tables on Metropoliman and restrained him, which gave Mukaido a chance to use the last of his strength to slay the villain with a heavy machine gun.  Metropoliman's death did more than end the threat he posed -- it also shifted the battle royale's tone away from violence and toward debate and philosophical discussion, which is what Mirai preferred. But he wouldn't be the one to take charge of the upcoming debate. RELATED: How Biblically Accurate are the Angels in Platinum End?          When Yuito Susumu Called For A Peaceful Summit                 Not long after Metropoliman's death, the youngest God candidate, Yuito Susumu, made his move. He appeared on live TV and encouraged the remaining candidates to join him in peaceful talks on who should become God and why, a plan Mirai and his ally Saki cautiously agreed to.  This helped shift Platinum End from a battle anime to something more akin to its Death Note progenitor, complete with the use of media, mind games and schemes within schemes. Susumu meant well, but other God candidates such as Nakaumi Shuji and Professor Yoneda would complicate Susumu's efforts to vote peacefully for a new God. Soon, it was Yoneda who ran the show, not Susumu. RELATED: Platinum End: Mirai Prepares for His Final Battle - and He May Have to Kill          When Professor Yoneda Vowed To Kill The God Creature                 The brilliant but reclusive professor Yoneda Gaku, the final God candidate to appear, wanted to end the battle royale in a whole new way. He didn't want to fight and become a classist king like Metropoliman, nor did he desire to vote for a new God. Instead, the cynical Yoneda proposed a shocking new theory: that humans' collective prayers and emotions created God, similar to negative emotions creating curses in Jujutsu Kaisen, and Yoneda didn't want such a false deity to deceive humanity with false hope.  So he hatched a bold plan to slay most other God candidates, then have his ally Nakaumi and himself kill one another to ensure no one won the competition. This would ensure God would never be replaced, and the very idea of this being would die out. RELATED: Platinum End's Professor Yoneda Echoes Hyuga Neji's Darkest Beliefs in Naruto          When Nakaumi Destroyed Himself As God                 In the end, Nakaumi was chosen as the new God and ascended to the heavens as an enlightened being. There, he saw for himself just how many people across the world wanted to end their own lives and he felt powerless to aid them. That, combined with his own self-destructive desires, led God-Nakaumi to destroy himself with a giant white arrow -- then chaos ensued.  This had an apocalyptic impact not just on Platinum End's main characters, but all of humanity and the angels as well. Everyone was wiped out -- but in the end, Mirai and Saki died happily in each other's arms and achieved their true platinum end. They were the winners after all. For more information on the warning signs and prevention of suicide, click here. If you or someone you know is in emotional distress or considering suicide, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255). If you live outside the U.S., click here for a list of international hotlines.
